Organs/Tissues: Human colon (e.g. UC-derived organoids) + liver (hepatocytes) + immune compartments
Physiological/Pathological: Both – normal cross-talk or disease states (e.g. ulcerative colitis + liver inflammation)
Cell Source: Primary patient-derived colon tissue (organoids), primary or iPSC-derived hepatocytes, T-cells, macrophages
Multiple Cell Types: Yes. Each organ compartment can hold multiple cell types (epithelial, fibroblasts, etc.)
Stromal Cells: Yes, included in organ compartments (intestinal mesenchyme, hepatic stellates)
Tissue-resident Immune: Yes (Kupffer in liver, local macrophages in colon tissue)
Circulating Immune: Yes, T-cells or PBMCs introduced into the common perfusion circuit
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Yes, compartments fluidically connected to replicate systemic interactions
Air-Liquid Interface: No, usually tissues submerged in common medium with on-board pumps
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, each tissue may include ECM scaffold/hydrogel (e.g. collagen) in its compartment
3D Scaffold: Yes, organoids or tissue constructs placed in each compartment
Notable Features: Captures immune-mediated gut-liver axis inflammation; user can add triggers to see multi-organ response
Plate/Format (Throughput): One integrated device with multiple compartments. Very low throughput (~1 system per device)
Max Culture Duration: Weeks; stable multi-organ viability with built-in micro-pumps
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, open-top compartments allow microscopic observation of tissues
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, can sample shared medium for cytokines, metabolites, drug levels
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Yes, compartments are accessible for tissue removal, single-cell analysis
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, entire colon or liver constructs can be fixed for histology or molecular assays
Readouts - TEER: No integrated electrodes; rely on functional/molecular barrier assays
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: No, typically external analysis for media or endpoint readouts
Dead Volume: Relatively low, thanks to integrated pumps & small channels, but shared perfusion circuit
Perfused: Yes, microfluidic channels + on-board pumps circulate media and immune cells
Gas Mix Controlled: Incubator-based environment only (no separate O2 controllers).
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Yes, can dynamically add cells/factors, adjust flow rates, sample at intervals
model_availability: Product + collaboration/service (platform from MIT spin-out). Not a disposable plate

Organs/Tissues: Up to 10 human tissues: liver, lung, heart, brain, kidney, etc. plus immune cells
Physiological/Pathological: Both – multi-organ homeostasis or complex disease (cancer metastasis, multi-organ toxicity)
Cell Source: Primary or iPSC-derived tissues for each organ; user-defined combos of cell lines, patient cells
Multiple Cell Types: Yes, each organ compartment can hold multi-cell-type constructs (endothelial + parenchymal + stromal, etc.)
Stromal Cells: Yes, included in each tissue module if desired
Tissue-resident Immune: Yes, e.g. macrophages in liver or alveolar macrophages in lung compartment
Circulating Immune: Yes, T/NK cells, monocytes in the common perfusate for systemic immune response
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Yes, fluidic circuit interlinks all organ compartments for holistic ‘human body’ simulation
Air-Liquid Interface: Typically no, or user must specifically create an ALI in a lung compartment. Usually submerged flow
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, each organ typically includes an ECM scaffold or hydrogel for 3D structure
3D Scaffold: Yes, organoids or tissue slices on scaffolds. On-board pump ensures perfusion
Notable Features: Simultaneous multi-organ interplay, custom flow paths, real-time control; advanced disease or PK/PD modeling
Plate/Format (Throughput): Single integrated device, extremely low throughput (1 multi-organ system per device). Possibly run a few in parallel
Max Culture Duration: Weeks or more, sustaining multi-organ viability and function
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, compartments are open or transparent for microscope access (though physically large)
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, shared medium can be sampled to assess cross-organ metabolism, secreted signals
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Yes, each organ tissue can be removed or biopsied mid/endpoint
Readouts - TEER: No integrated TEER system. Rely on functional readouts
Readouts - MEA: No built-in arrays. Potential external adaptation for neural/heart compartments
Dead Volume: Relatively low for multi-organ system due to integrated micro-pumps & short channels
Perfused: Yes, closed-loop microfluidic circulation across all compartments
Gas Mix Controlled: Via incubator environment, no dedicated on-chip oxygenation
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Yes, can modulate flow, add stimuli or immune cells, sample compartments
model_availability: Product + specialized service/partnership (research platform from MIT spin-off). Not a mass-market consumable
